message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has hyperkalemia, which can cause bradycardia and peaked T waves on ECG. β-antagonists can worsen bradycardia and are contraindicated in patients with hyperkalemia. Glucose and insulin infusion, sodium bicarbonate, and calcium resonium are all treatments for hyperkalemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s tall peaked T waves and high serum potassium levels suggest hyperkalemia. Administering a β-antagonist, which can worsen the condition, should be avoided. The other options, including glucose-insulin, sodium bicarbonate, and calcium resonium, can help reduce serum potassium levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's tall peaked T waves and bradycardia suggest hyperkalemia. Administering a β-antagonist may worsen the condition by further reducing heart rate and worsening the cardiac output. Treatment options for hyperkalemia include glucose and insulin, sodium bicarbonate, and calcium resonium.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has hyperkalemia, which can be worsened by administering a β-antagonist, as it can cause a shift of potassium from the intracellular to the extracellular space. Options A, B, and C are all treatments for hyperkalemia. Glucose and insulin can help drive potassium into cells, sodium bicarbonate can correct acidosis and cause some potassium to shift intracellularly, and Calcium resonium can lower serum potassium by exchanging calcium ions for potassium ions in the gut.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The elevated serum potassium and tall peaked T waves suggest hyperkalemia. Administering a β-antagonist may worsen the condition as it may further decrease the heart rate and impair cardiac output. Treatment options for hyperkalemia include 50 mL of 50% glucose solution with 10 units of soluble insulin by intravenous infusion, 50 ml of Sodium bicarbonate (8.4%), and Calcium resonium.

We refer to MedicineNet for help. The patient has hyperkalemia, which can cause bradycardia and tall peaked T waves on ECG. Administering a β-antagonist can worsen this patient’s condition by further decreasing heart rate and potentially causing heart block. The other options aim to lower serum potassium levels: glucose and insulin drive potassium into cells, bicarbonate corrects acidosis which can worsen hyperkalemia, and Calcium resonium binds to and removes excess potassium from the body.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient is presenting with hyperkalemia, and beta-blockers can worsen the condition by blocking the actions of the sympathetic nervous system, which can increase potassium levels. The other options are all potential treatments for hyperkalemia. Option A is using insulin to move potassium inside the cells, option B is using bicarbonate to shift potassium into cells, and option C is using calcium to stabilize the cardiac membrane potential.

We refer to the American College of Cardiology website for help. The patient has hyperkalemia, which can cause bradycardia and tall peaked T waves. Administering a β-antagonist would further slow the heart rate and worsen the patient’s condition. The other options, glucose-insulin infusion, sodium bicarbonate, and calcium resonium, are all treatments for hyperkalemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has hyperkalemia, which can cause a slow heart rate, seen as sinus bradycardia on the ECG. Administering a β-antagonist can worsen this condition by further slowing down the heart rate. Option (A) is the correct treatment for hyperkalemia, as insulin can help drive potassium into cells along with glucose. Option (B) is used for metabolic acidosis, not hyperkalemia. Option (C) is a potassium-binding resin, which can help lower potassium levels.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has hyperkalemia (elevated serum potassium) which can cause bradycardia and tall peaked T waves on ECG. β-antagonists can further decrease the heart rate and worsen the patient’s condition. Glucose and insulin, sodium bicarbonate, and calcium resonium are all treatments for hyperkalemia.
